title: Suggestions for a bitmap typeface (others then Screen Matrix, Knit Map and Folk Art)
content:
Hello!

I’m looking for a bitmap typeface with a construction similar to these ones:  
Screen Matrix, Knit map and Folk art.  
I would like it to be more neutral then folk art but more gentle and delicate then Screen Matrix.  
Do you have any suggestions that might help me?

Thanks a lot in advance.

comments.content:
[Gretel](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009143437/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fountain/gretel/) and [FF Nelio](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009143437/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_nelio/) might not be what you’re looking for, but they are others in this elegant pixel genre.

You might also like [FF Screenstar](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009143437/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_screenstar/) which is a simple pixel sans, but a tad more style than FF Screen Matrix.

Nick Shinn’s [Panoptica](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009143437/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/shinntype/panoptica_pixel/) is also very interesting and [Unibody](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009143437/http:/www.underware.nl/site2/index.php3?id1=unibody&id2=overview) is without doubt the finest free pixel family.

Here are a few others to try:

- [DT Corsa & DT Ciny](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009143437/http:/www.distype.be/)
- [Memoria Regular](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009143437/http:/pixelfonts.style-force.net/)
- [Methodic](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009143437/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=AMT0000012)

As an aside, does anybody know what happened to [Atomic Media](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009143437/http:/atomicmedia.net/)?

\> Unibody is without doubt the finest free pixel family.

Based on its weaknesses (primitive construction,  
dysfunctional italic) I myself doubt plenty.

On the other hand (?) it is good enough that  
they did the field a disservice by making it free.

hhp

_Based on its weaknesses (primitive construction, dysfunctional italic)_

I’ve not yet seen an 8 pixel high font that doesn’t have primitive construction and dysfunctional italics. How could it be anything else?

I said primitive <cite>construction</cite>. Using discrete squares to render out the pixels is the lowest form of pixelfont; it causes (at least) two problems, plus it makes the font unnecessarily large in K. As for the Italic, the real problem I guess is simply pretending it is one. If they had called it Cursive then I would have no issue, since users would know what it’s not.

hhp

Another problem with Unibody is its obsession with ductus, even in such a coarse medium/size; look at how ungainly the bold “y” is. Dogma interfering with Design.

hhp
Hrant, my font anatomy/vocabulary is very limited. What is ’ductus’ in relation to type?

It refers to the “action” of the broad-nib pen (when used by a right-hander).  
If you’re smelling a rat, you have a good nose.

hhp

\>\> Unibody is without doubt the finest free pixel family.

\> Based on its weaknesses (primitive construction, dysfunctional italic) I myself doubt plenty.

Hrant, please point me to some pixel families that you prefer to Unibody.

I just said I have doubt, not that I could name  
offhand any <cite>free</cite>\* ones that are better. :-)

\* Your criterion above, and a good one.

hhp

_Ductus refers to the “action” of the broad-nib pen (when used by a right-hander).  
If you’re smelling a rat, you have a good nose._

Hrant, should I smell a rat? I first saw it merely as a design affectation but now I can see what you’re saying about the ductus of the bold y, v and w. Would I be right in saying that the Ductal Logic hasn’t been consistently applied to the middle upright of the bold w?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009143437im_/http:/typophile.com/files/unibody-family_5642.gif)

There are free pixel fonts galore here...

[http://pentacom.jp/soft/ex/font/museum.cgi](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009143437/http:/pentacom.jp/soft/ex/font/museum.cgi "http://pentacom.jp/soft/ex/font/museum.cgi")

...with, I would guess, a broad range of Ductal Logics. (my new favourite phrase :)

My point was forcing ductal logic on a 10ppem\* font (or really any font) comes at the expense of Good Design. The “w” on the other hand goes against ductal logic and <cite>still</cite> manages to look crappy.

\* I don’t know where people get 8.

\> a broad range of Ductal Logics.

Yes, and we sadly only have one single font  
so far that properly breaks the logic: Legato.

hhp
